Our Solar System in Real-Time

Solar System

The Sun

  • Description: The Sun is a G-type main-sequence star at the center of our solar system. It is composed primarily of hydrogen and helium, and its gravity holds the solar system together.
  • Distance From Sun:0 AU (Astronomical Unit).
  • Distance From Earth:149.6 million kilometers (1 AU).
  • Radius: 696,340 km.
  • Revolution: N/A (Sun does not revolve around anything in the solar system)
  • Rotation:25–36 days (depending on latitude).
  • Planets:Many Planets and dwarfs.
  • Temperature and Climate:Surface temperature is ~5,500°C. The core can reach over 15 million °C. Constantly emits solar radiation, including solar flares and solar wind.

Mercury

    • Description:Mercury is the smallest and innermost planet in the solar system, known for its extreme temperature variations and proximity to the Sun.
    • Distance From Sun:57.9 million kilometers (0.39 AU).
    • Distance From Earth:77 million kilometers (average).
    • Radius:2,439.7 km.
    • Revolution:88 Earth days.
    • Rotation:59 Earth days.
    • Moons:None.
    • Temperature and Climate: Daytime temperatures can reach 430°C, while at night they can drop to -180°C. Mercury has almost no atmosphere to retain heat.

Venus

  • Description:Venus is often called Earth’s twin due to its similar size, but it has an extremely thick, toxic atmosphere primarily composed of carbon dioxide and sulfuric acid clouds.
  • Distance From Sun:108.2 million kilometers (0.72 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:41 million kilometers (closest approach).
  • Radius: 6,051.8 km.
  • Revolution:225 Earth days.
  • Rotation:243 Earth days (retrograde).
  • Moons:None.
  • Temperature and Climate:Surface temperature averages around 465°C, making it the hottest planet due to its thick atmosphere creating a greenhouse effect.

Earth

  • Description:Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known planet to support life. It has a diverse climate and liquid water on its surface.
  • Distance From Sun:149.6 million kilometers (1 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:N/A.
  • Radius: 6,371 km.
  • Revolution:365.25 days.
  • Rotation:24 hours.
  • Moons: 1 (Moon).
  • Temperature and Climate:The global average temperature is 15°C. The climate varies significantly depending on location, ranging from tropical to polar.

Moon

  • Description: Earth's only natural satellite, the Moon is the fifth-largest moon in the solar system and plays a vital role in controlling Earth's tides.
  • Distance From Sun:150 million kilometers (on average, same as Earth).
  • Distance From Earth:384,400 km.
  • Radius:1,737.4 km.
  • Revolution:27.3 Earth days.
  • Rotation:27.3 Earth days (synchronous rotation with Earth).
  • Moons:None.
  • Temperature and Climate:Temperatures range from -173°C at night to 127°C during the day. The Moon has no atmosphere, so it does not have a climate in the way Earth does.

Mars

  • Description:Known as the Red Planet, Mars is a cold desert world with a thin atmosphere. It has the tallest volcano and the deepest canyon in the solar system.
  • Distance From Sun:227.9 million kilometers (1.52 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:54.6 million kilometers (closest approach).
  • Radius:3,389.5 km.
  • Revolution:687 Earth days.
  • Rotation:24.6 hours.
  • Moons: 2 (Phobos and Deimos).
  • Temperature and Climate:Temperatures can range from -125°C at the poles during winter to 20°C near the equator during summer. Mars has a thin atmosphere composed mostly of carbon dioxide.

Jupiter

  • Description:Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system, known for its Great Red Spot, a massive storm that has been raging for centuries, and its many moons.
  • Distance From Sun:778.5 million kilometers (5.2 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:588 million kilometers (average).
  • Radius:69,911 km.
  • Revolution:11.86 Earth years.
  • Rotation:9.9 hours.
  • Moons:95 confirmed moons (including Ganymede, the largest moon in the solar system).
  • Temperature and Climate:Average cloud-top temperature is -145°C. Jupiter has no solid surface, and its atmosphere is mostly hydrogen and helium, with intense storms and high-speed winds.

Saturn

  • Description:Saturn is the second-largest planet in the solar system, famous for its stunning ring system made of ice and rock particles.
  • Distance From Sun:1.43 billion kilometers (9.58 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:1.2 billion kilometers (average).
  • Radius:58,232 km.
  • Revolution: 29.45 Earth years.
  • Rotation:10.7 hours.
  • Moons:145 confirmed moons (including Titan, the second-largest moon in the solar system).
  • Temperature and Climate:Average cloud-top temperature is -178°C. Saturn’s atmosphere is similar to Jupiter's, consisting mostly of hydrogen and helium.

Uranus

  • Description:Uranus is an ice giant with a unique tilt that causes it to orbit the Sun on its side. Its atmosphere contains methane, giving it a blue-green color.
  • Distance From Sun:2.87 billion kilometers (19.2 AU).
  • Distance From Earth: 2.6 billion kilometers (average).
  • Radius: 25,362 km.
  • Revolution: 84 Earth years.
  • Rotation: 17.2 hours (retrograde).
  • Moons: 27 confirmed moons (including Titania and Oberon).
  • Temperature and Climate:Average temperature is -224°C. Uranus has a cold, featureless atmosphere dominated by hydrogen, helium, and methane.

Neptune

  • Description:Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun and is known for its deep blue color and strong winds, some of the fastest in the solar system.
  • Distance From Sun:4.5 billion kilometers (30.07 AU).
  • Distance From Earth:4.3 billion kilometers (average).
  • Radius:24,622 km.
  • Revolution:164.8 Earth years.
  • Rotation:16.1 hours.
  • Moons:14 confirmed moons (including Triton, which orbits in the opposite direction to Neptune's rotation).
  • Temperature and Climate: Average temperature is -214°C. Neptune's atmosphere contains hydrogen, helium, and methane, with dynamic weather and high-speed winds.

    • Pluto

    • Description: Pluto is a dwarf planet located in the Kuiper Belt, a region of icy bodies beyond Neptune. Once considered the ninth planet, it was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006 by the International Astronomical Union (IAU). Pluto is composed mostly of ice and rock.
    • Distance From Sun:5.9 billion kilometers (39.5 AU).
    • Distance From Earth: Varies, but on average about 4.67 billion kilometers.
    • Radius: 1,188.3 km.
    • Revolution:248 Earth years.
    • Rotation:6.4 Earth days (retrograde, similar to Venus).
    • Moons: 5 (Charon, Nix, Hydra, Kerberos, Styx). Charon is the largest moon and is nearly half the size of Pluto itself, forming a binary system with Pluto.
    • Temperature and Climate:Pluto's surface temperature averages around -229°C. Its atmosphere is thin and primarily composed of nitrogen, with traces of methane and carbon monoxide. The atmosphere expands when Pluto is closer to the Sun and contracts as it moves farther away, resulting in volatile changes.

      • Asteriods

      • Description:Asteroids are rocky remnants from the early solar system that primarily orbit in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. They vary widely in size and composition.
      • Distance From Sun:Varies, but the asteroid belt is located 329 million to 478 million kilometers from the Sun (2.2 to 3.2 AU).
      • Distance From Earth:Varies depending on the specific asteroid; some come as close as a few million kilometers.
      • Radius: Varies greatly, from a few meters to hundreds of kilometers (e.g., Ceres has a radius of ~473 km).
      • Revolution:Varies, typically between 3 to 6 Earth years for asteroids in the asteroid belt.
      • Rotation:Varies by individual asteroid.
      • Moons:Some asteroids have moons (e.g., asteroid Ida has a moon named Dactyl).
      • Temperature and Climate:Varies depending on the asteroid's location and composition; surface temperatures can range from -73°C to -170°C. Asteroids have no atmosphere and are generally inactive.
